reviewText:
Ok at first I thought this game was dumb and the graphics sucked, because all you do is stand in a really small cave with floating rocks in it that will break apart if you hit them. So I quit the game and didn't think any more about it. Then I saw on reddit someone said this game is going to be awesome, and someone agreed after they realized you can break the walls of your cave. I was like whaaa????

So i go home and fire it back up. First thing I do is hit the cave wall, just once.

Err. Mah. Gerd.

Mind completely blown. I cannot WAIT until the full game is released now. Freakin EPIC!

reviewText: Brief but amazing, Prologue" delights in its abstract nature - and defies classification as it is simultaenously not a game yet engages the user at a blissfully intuitive level. It is an experience that really can only be conveyed by trying it
date: and is sure to delight anyone who has ever gazed at the stars. I hope it is truely just a prologue
recommended: and look forward to seeing more.\n\n"

reviewText:
This is...there aren't really words. It's beautiful. Existential. I replayed it a few times, and intend to play it many more until the full version arrives.

The second time I played it I just lied on the floor and felt like I was floating. Absolutely amazing.
This is VR. It transports you to another world.
To anyone that says resolution" or "SDE" or "it's just like wii motes"...I implore you to try this.
It will change your mind...reminded me of 2001: A Space Odyssey. And that's a huge compliment..."

reviewText:
THIS IS AMAZING

I'm a bit of an adrenaline junkie, in my life I rode lots of rollercoasters, went house running, went sky diving... nothing I ever did was as terrifyingly awesome as this short demo, no joke.
I started the game knowing nothing at all about it, didn't even see a picture. I had no idea what's coming up, and boy did it take me by by surprise. It wasn't until the fourth play-through that I could keep my cool.

Like others mentioned, this demo is very well suited as an introduction to VR because the controls are so simple and yet it's such a convincing experience.

reviewText: Irrational Exuberance is the very first game I have people try when they're using the Vive for the first time.  It's also a game I wish I could experience for the first time again whenever I load it up.   It's a short, but breathtaking experience that truly transports players into a very unique visualization of space.  There is a huge sense of discovery, and so far everyone I've had play it, has experienced it through very different perspectives.  The game is incredibly immersive from the moment it starts, and keeps you curious of whats beyond the prologue's boundaries.  I don't want to spoil too much, but I'd encourage anyone with a vive to check it out.

reviewText:
Jaw dropping.

I tried this as one of the last remaining VR games, so I've seen a lot of stuff before. But it still made my jaw drop. It isn't much of a game, rather an experience and you are part of it. The music, the sounds and the graphics style is what made it for me. Everything felt so crisp and amazing. It's hard to describe but it was magic.

Sadly it's very short but I guess that's why it is free and a prologue. The only criticism I have is the weird transition effect when you change levels. It hurt my eyes and I needed to close them to not lose my sanity.

Thanks for making this! Looking forward to the full game!

reviewText:
This demo is MIND-BLOWING!

I've never experienced anything like this before. It's a FANTASTIC experience. This is what VR was made for!

It takes just a couple of minutes to complete but it leaves a lasting impression on your mind, I'll guarantee it. What you will experience is unlike anything you've experienced in real life. It's mind-boggling.

I realize I'm throwing around superlatives, but this demo deserves them.

It looks spectacularly good and makes really good use of the Vive's room scale features. The audio is great too.

This is without a doubt the best thing VR has to offer right now. Only TheBlu offers a similarly great experience.

Can't wait for the full product to be released!

reviewText:
It was one of if not my most immersive experience I had with the HTC Vive.
It used room-scale and motion controllers incredibly well and the sense of scale and overwhelming sense of being out there in the huge abyss of space was mind blowing.

It sent strong tingles throughout my entire body and I've at least played it a dozen times now and I cannot wait for what the full version has to offer.

Very emotional experience.

First off I need to preface this with my fear of heights.  This game literally brought me to my knees in fear, but I knew I had to keep going.  It's so incredible, so immersive, that I wanted to look at everything yet every time I really looked around my real fear of heights would take over.  I kneeled down so I could feel more stable and went through the entire experience on my knees.  It's probably the most amazing experience I've had on the Vive so far.  You absolutely have to try it, even if you have a fear of heights.  It's even that more amazing that you're playing a game on a computer that invokes your real fears and emotions in that way.  I would still do it again, even knowing what it's like.  It's truely an incredible experience.
I have no idea what this game is going to involve but it is scifi and it is beautiful. Certainly worth a try just to get a taste of a good VR experience. Get it. Space room scale is cool.

This demo is so amazing and immersive, so much so that I could not finish it!

Let me preface this by saying that I personally have a fear of underwater depths which I can generally control. Well this demo has one scene where you're in what seems like an underwater location. It resembles being underwater so much that I literally had to take the headset off because of the immense fear that took over me. The fear that I felt was so REAL yet as I was taking the headset off I was literally laughing out loud to myself because I was also in awe that this demo and VR could make me feel this way!

Guys, please know that this is a compliment. I have not felt this level of emotion in a game in a LONG time!

This is going into my rotation when I demo VR to my friends.

Keep it up!
I don't know wtf im doing, but I like it. Make more...

A Warning.

Whilst playing this I became so irrationally exuberant that I was determined to break every last piece of my space-cave, just because I could.  This wouldn't have been a problem except that the piece of rock directly above my head, although in a different universe, nonetheless shared it's physical coordinates with a halogen light bulb in real life.
As soon as I'd punched out the rock, I smelt burning.  Uh-oh, I thought, better check on the real world.
I then realised that in this universe I had punched the light bulb, which had replied by exploding into a zillion tiny fragments.  A bit like my space cave, but different in that:
a. The pieces were much much smaller and sharper.
b. There were a very great number of them.
c. I was to spend the next hour on my hands and knees slowly picking them all out of the carpet.

The burning smell was smouldering carpet. Oops.
However, the Vive controller was NOT DAMAGED, so a happy ending.

So now I know to switch off the light and remove the bulb before hitting invisible space rocks.
Devs:  In future, please avoid placing things that are fun to hit in the same place as things that aren't fun to hit IRL. Thank you.

10/10 Would shower myself with hot glass again.

reviewText: Really neat style, but the game needs better tuning for the Chaperone system - in my near-max space, I was constantly getting the Chaperone walls in places where the game wanted me to interact. This has not been an issue in any other game I've played yet.\n\nVery, very cool, but that aspect completely broke immersion and presence.

reviewText: I think most of the people haven't gotten to try other experiences yet because this is just an ok experience.  You hit walls and break rocks and see a non interactive space scene (yes you get to break more rocks).  The initial cave's walls are also too close to the play area walls (I currently have a 3m x 2.5m play area) so that at a minimum chaperone pops up when you break the cave and you might hit your real walls (I did).  It's free but there are more fun things to do in VR, spend your time more wisely.

Product received for free

This is the first review i have ever done for a game on steam. I simply had to make one for this experience. This is amazing, every VR developer needs to experience this and take notes.

This will be the first experience i show to people when they use my HTC Vive.

The only words i have to effectively describe this experience is something the along the lines of pure curiosity driven serendipity.

When i show this experience to people, there will be no talking or disturbing them, there will be no sound, there will be no helping, Even if they are having a hard time figuring out what to do, you still do not give guidance, it is THEIR experience. Usually when i bring people over i have my monitor in a visibile spot so people can see what the person is doing in VR. But from this point on especially for this experience. Im going to start turning the monitor away, so people can't see whats going on inside. This experience is simply too novel to allow it to be spoiled with flat images.
OMG blew my mind

reviewText:
+ Great VR Showcase
+ Excellent Space Theme
+ Invokes curiosity / wonder
+ Controllers encourages movement
- No visual indicator for play-area edges

Irrational Exuberance leans more towards science fiction than cold hard facts. It's space, but there are many object within reach or just near by. Fully tracked controllers have you walking forward to touch peices of astroids and debry.
